yaml.author: {{< var instructor.name >}}
yaml.subtitle: Wealth · Themes

revealjs.footer: {{< var course.number >}} {{< var course.title >}} | {{< var course.semester >}}

markdown.markdown:
::: columns ::: {style="font-size:1.5rem"} ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Non-financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Dwellings (owner-occupied residence, other real estate) - Consumer durables (vehicles, etc.) - Valuables - Intellectual property ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Currency and deposits - Net equity in own unincorporated business - Mututal funds and investment funds - (Private) Pensions funds - Bonds and other debt securities - Shares and other equity - Life insurance funds -Other financial assets ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Liabilities**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Owner-occupied residence loans - Consumer durable loans (e.g. for vehicles) - Other investment loans (collateralized) - Other loans (e.g. education loans) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.absolute top="70%" left="60%" .textbox .fragment .fade-up} No human, social and cultural capital; No public social security pensions (marketable vs. augmented wealth) ::: ::: {.aside} Source: @oecd:2013 ::: ## HFCS sampling and underreporting ::: {.incremental style="font-size:1.8rem"} - Target population in Austria: [3.9 million households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Gross sample in HFCS 2017: [6,280 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Realized interviews: [3,072 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Response rate in HFCS 2017: [approx. 50%]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Residual: [refused interviews]{.marker-hl}, invalid addresses, households not available, etc. ::: ::: {.absolute bottom="5%" left="10%" width="800px" .textbox .fragment .fade-up style="font-size:1.7rem;padding:0.5rem 1rem;" .altlist} - Response refusal correlates with wealth and is highest at the top [@vermeulen:2016] - Wealthy households own a greater number of assets and miss some components more easily [@kennickell:1999] ::: ## Upstream strategy against underreporting: Oversampling {.smaller} - Undercoverage and Underreporting - Oversampling is crucial for wealth surveys - Oversampling in HFCS 2017: :belgium: :cyprus: :de: :estonia: :es: :finland: :fr: :greece: :croatia: :hungary: :ireland: :latvia: :lithuania: :luxembourg: :poland: :portugal: :slovakia: - No oversampling: :austria: :it: :malta: :netherlands: :slovenia: - How does oversampling work? - External personal wealth data (:fr: :es:) - List of streets with high-income people (:de: :slovakia:) - Income tax data (:luxembourg: 20% of the sample from top 10% earners) - Regions with higher average income (:poland:) ## Downstream strategy against underreporting: Pareto estimation {.smaller} - Pareto-Distribution is a sensible approximation to the distribution of large wealth - Two parameters: - Threshold for "large" wealth $m$ - Pareto-Index $\alpha$ $$P_i(x_i) = Pr(X_i \leqslant x_i) = 1 - \left(\frac{m_i}{x_i}\right)^{\alpha_i}$$ $$\forall ~\text{implicates} ~i = 1...5 \wedge x_i \geqslant m_i$$ ::: {.fragment .fade-in} [A smaller $\alpha$ means greater inequality. Empirically, $\alpha$ often is around 1.5 for wealth.]{.bubble .bubble-bottom-left .absolute top="30%" right="0%" style="--bubcol: var(--bubcol-red);max-width:350px;font-size:1.2rem;"} ::: ::: {.aside} Reading recommendation: @gabaix:2016 ::: ## European Rich List Database (ERLDB) and HFCS {.smaller} ![](img/rlmap_col.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} ::: {.aside} Source: @disslbacher:2020 ::: ## Cumulative density function of wealth in Germany {.smaller} ![](img/ccdf_col.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} ::: {.aside} Source: @disslbacher:2020 ::: ## Net wealth distribution in Austria ```{r waffle} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' #| fig-width: 10 #| fig-height: 4.5 library(tidyverse) library(MetBrewer) library(msthemes) library(waffle) wineq <- tribble( ~group, ~share, ~popshare, "Top 1%", 38.9, 1, "Top 2-5%", 16.2, 4, "Top 6-10%", 10.6, 5, "Top 11-50%", 31.4, 40, "Bottom 50%", 2.8, 50 ) |> mutate(group = factor(group, levels = rev(group)), labpos = cumsum(share)- 0.5*share) wineq |> select(group, `Wealth share`=share, `Population share`=popshare) |> pivot_longer(cols = -group, names_to = "cat", values_to = "value") |> mutate(value = round(value,0)) |> ggplot(aes(fill=group, values=value)) + geom_waffle(color = "white", size=1.125, n_rows = 5, na.rm = F) + facet_wrap(~cat, ncol=1) + scale_x_discrete(expand=c(0,0)) + scale_y_discrete(expand=c(0,0)) + scale_fill_manual(values = met.brewer("Juarez"), guide = guide_legend(reverse=T, keywidth = 0.5, keyheight = 2)) + theme_ms(grid=F,alttf=T) + theme(strip.text.x = element_text(size=20,margin=margin(b=5, t=5)), legend.text = element_text(size=14), legend.title=element_blank()) + coord_equal() + theme_enhance_waffle() ``` ## Income and wealth inequality across Europe ```{r ginis} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' #| fig-width: 10 #| fig-height: 4.5 load("data/ginidat.RData") ginidat |> ggplot(aes(x=reorder(geo, rank, na.rm=T))) + geom_segment(aes(y = 0, yend = values, xend=geo), size = 0.1, color="grey70") + geom_point(aes(y=values, group = type, shape = type, color = type), size = 3) + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = mean(values[type=="Income"])), size = 0.1, linetype = "longdash") + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = mean(values[type=="Wealth"], na.rm=T)), size = 0.1, linetype = "longdash") + annotate("text", x = 24, y = 68, label = "Average", size = 3) + scale_color_manual(values = met.brewer("Juarez"), labels = c("Income" = "Disposable income (Eurostat)", "Wealth" = "Net wealth (HFCS)")) + scale_shape_manual(values = c(19,17), labels = c("Income" = "Disposable income (Eurostat)", "Wealth" = "Net wealth (HFCS)")) + theme_ms() + labs(x="",y="Gini index") + theme(legend.title = element_blank(), legend.text = element_text(size=14), axis.title = element_text(size = 14), axis.text = element_text(size = 12), legend.position = "bottom", axis.title.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()) ``` ## Global income and wealth inequality {.smaller} ![](img/incwealthineq.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: ## Private and public wealth {.smaller} ![](img/privpubwealth.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: # Themes ![](../../data/img/avatar_break.png){fig-align="center" height=350} ::: footer ::: ## Themes
```{r themes} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' #| fig-width: 10 #| fig-height: 5.5 library(patchwork) mtcars2 <- within(mtcars, { vs <- factor(vs, labels = c("V-shaped", "Straight")) am <- factor(am, labels = c("Automatic", "Manual")) cyl <- factor(cyl) gear <- factor(gear) }) p <- ggplot(mtcars2) + geom_point(aes(x = wt, y = mpg, colour = gear)) + labs(x = "Weight (1000 lbs)", y = "Fuel economy (mpg)", colour = "Gears") + theme(plot.title = element_text(family = "Roboto Condensed")) p1 <- p + labs(title = "theme_grey()") + theme_grey(base_size = 7) p2 <- p + labs(title = "theme_bw()") + theme_bw(base_size = 7) p3 <- p + labs(title = "theme_minimal()") + theme_minimal(base_size = 7) p4 <- p + labs(title = "theme_dark()") + theme_dark(base_size = 7) p5 <- p + labs(title = "theme_classic()") + theme_classic(base_size = 7) p6 <- p + labs(title = "theme_void()") + theme_void(base_size = 7) (p1 + p2 + p3) / (p4 + p5 + p6) & theme(plot.title = element_text(family = "Roboto Condensed", size = 16), plot.margin = margin(b = 2, r = 1, unit = "lines")) ```
## Main theme components {.medium} ```{r theming} #| echo: true #| eval: false data |> ggplot(aes(x = var1, y = var2)) |> geom_line() + theme_minimal() + theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "red"), panel.grid.x = element_blank(), axis.line.x = element_line(linewidth = 1.2), legend.text = element_text(size = 7), legend.position = "top") ```
::: {.tbl-classic} | Plot | Panel | Axis | Legend | Strip | |------|-------|------|--------|-------| | background | background | title | background | background | | title | border | text | key | placement | | subtitle | grid | ticks | title | text | | caption | spacing | line | text | | | margin | | | position | | ::: ## Bibliography {.bibstyle} :::footer :::

## Definition of private wealth {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {style="font-size:1.5rem"} ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Non-financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Dwellings (owner-occupied residence, other real estate) - Consumer durables (vehicles, etc.) - Valuables - Intellectual property ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Currency and deposits - Net equity in own unincorporated business - Mututal funds and investment funds - (Private) Pensions funds - Bonds and other debt securities - Shares and other equity - Life insurance funds -Other financial assets ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Liabilities**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Owner-occupied residence loans - Consumer durable loans (e.g. for vehicles) - Other investment loans (collateralized) - Other loans (e.g. education loans) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.absolute top="70%" left="60%" .textbox .fragment .fade-up} No human, social and cultural capital; No public social security pensions (marketable vs. augmented wealth) ::: ::: {.aside} Source: @oecd:2013 ::: ## HFCS sampling and underreporting ::: {.incremental style="font-size:1.8rem"} - Target population in Austria: [3.9 million households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Gross sample in HFCS 2017: [6,280 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Realized interviews: [3,072 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Response rate in HFCS 2017: [approx. 50%]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Residual: [refused interviews]{.marker-hl}, invalid addresses, households not available, etc. ::: ::: {.absolute bottom="5%" left="10%" width="800px" .textbox .fragment .fade-up style="font-size:1.7rem;padding:0.5rem 1rem;" .altlist} - Response refusal correlates with wealth and is highest at the top [@vermeulen:2016] - Wealthy households own a greater number of assets and miss some components more easily [@kennickell:1999] ::: ## Upstream strategy against underreporting: Oversampling {.smaller} - Undercoverage and Underreporting - Oversampling is crucial for wealth surveys - Oversampling in HFCS 2017: :belgium: :cyprus: :de: :estonia: :es: :finland: :fr: :greece: :croatia: :hungary: :ireland: :latvia: :lithuania: :luxembourg: :poland: :portugal: :slovakia: - No oversampling: :austria: :it: :malta: :netherlands: :slovenia: - How does oversampling work? - External personal wealth data (:fr: :es:) - List of streets with high-income people (:de: :slovakia:) - Income tax data (:luxembourg: 20% of the sample from top 10% earners) - Regions with higher average income (:poland:) ## Downstream strategy against underreporting: Pareto estimation {.smaller} - Pareto-Distribution is a sensible approximation to the distribution of large wealth - Two parameters: - Threshold for "large" wealth $m$ - Pareto-Index $\alpha$ $$P_i(x_i) = Pr(X_i \leqslant x_i) = 1 - \left(\frac{m_i}{x_i}\right)^{\alpha_i}$$ $$\forall ~\text{implicates} ~i = 1...5 \wedge x_i \geqslant m_i$$ ::: {.fragment .fade-in} [A smaller $\alpha$ means greater inequality. Empirically, $\alpha$ often is around 1.5 for wealth.]{.bubble .bubble-bottom-left .absolute top="30%" right="0%" style="--bubcol: var(--bubcol-red);max-width:350px;font-size:1.2rem;"} ::: ::: {.aside} Reading recommendation: @gabaix:2016 ::: ## European Rich List Database (ERLDB) and HFCS {.smaller} ![](img/rlmap_col.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} ::: {.aside} Source: @disslbacher:2020 ::: ## Cumulative density function of wealth in Germany {.smaller} ![](img/ccdf_col.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} ::: {.aside} Source: @disslbacher:2020 ::: ## Net wealth distribution in Austria ```{r waffle} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' #| fig-width: 10 #| fig-height: 4.5 library(tidyverse) library(MetBrewer) library(msthemes) library(waffle) wineq <- tribble( ~group, ~share, ~popshare, "Top 1%", 38.9, 1, "Top 2-5%", 16.2, 4, "Top 6-10%", 10.6, 5, "Top 11-50%", 31.4, 40, "Bottom 50%", 2.8, 50 ) |> mutate(group = factor(group, levels = rev(group)), labpos = cumsum(share)- 0.5*share) wineq |> select(group, `Wealth share`=share, `Population share`=popshare) |> pivot_longer(cols = -group, names_to = "cat", values_to = "value") |> mutate(value = round(value,0)) |> ggplot(aes(fill=group, values=value)) + geom_waffle(color = "white", size=1.125, n_rows = 5, na.rm = F) + facet_wrap(~cat, ncol=1) + scale_x_discrete(expand=c(0,0)) + scale_y_discrete(expand=c(0,0)) + scale_fill_manual(values = met.brewer("Juarez"), guide = guide_legend(reverse=T, keywidth = 0.5, keyheight = 2)) + theme_ms(grid=F,alttf=T) + theme(strip.text.x = element_text(size=20,margin=margin(b=5, t=5)), legend.text = element_text(size=14), legend.title=element_blank()) + coord_equal() + theme_enhance_waffle() ``` ## Income and wealth inequality across Europe ```{r ginis} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' #| fig-width: 10 #| fig-height: 4.5 load("data/ginidat.RData") ginidat |> ggplot(aes(x=reorder(geo, rank, na.rm=T))) + geom_segment(aes(y = 0, yend = values, xend=geo), size = 0.1, color="grey70") + geom_point(aes(y=values, group = type, shape = type, color = type), size = 3) + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = mean(values[type=="Income"])), size = 0.1, linetype = "longdash") + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = mean(values[type=="Wealth"], na.rm=T)), size = 0.1, linetype = "longdash") + annotate("text", x = 24, y = 68, label = "Average", size = 3) + scale_color_manual(values = met.brewer("Juarez"), labels = c("Income" = "Disposable income (Eurostat)", "Wealth" = "Net wealth (HFCS)")) + scale_shape_manual(values = c(19,17), labels = c("Income" = "Disposable income (Eurostat)", "Wealth" = "Net wealth (HFCS)")) + theme_ms() + labs(x="",y="Gini index") + theme(legend.title = element_blank(), legend.text = element_text(size=14), axis.title = element_text(size = 14), axis.text = element_text(size = 12), legend.position = "bottom", axis.title.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()) ``` ## Global income and wealth inequality {.smaller} ![](img/incwealthineq.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: ## Private and public wealth {.smaller} ![](img/privpubwealth.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: # Themes ![](../../data/img/avatar_break.png){fig-align="center" height=350} ::: footer ::: ## Themes
```{r themes} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' #| fig-width: 10 #| fig-height: 5.5 library(patchwork) mtcars2 <- within(mtcars, { vs <- factor(vs, labels = c("V-shaped", "Straight")) am <- factor(am, labels = c("Automatic", "Manual")) cyl <- factor(cyl) gear <- factor(gear) }) p <- ggplot(mtcars2) + geom_point(aes(x = wt, y = mpg, colour = gear)) + labs(x = "Weight (1000 lbs)", y = "Fuel economy (mpg)", colour = "Gears") + theme(plot.title = element_text(family = "Roboto Condensed")) p1 <- p + labs(title = "theme_grey()") + theme_grey(base_size = 7) p2 <- p + labs(title = "theme_bw()") + theme_bw(base_size = 7) p3 <- p + labs(title = "theme_minimal()") + theme_minimal(base_size = 7) p4 <- p + labs(title = "theme_dark()") + theme_dark(base_size = 7) p5 <- p + labs(title = "theme_classic()") + theme_classic(base_size = 7) p6 <- p + labs(title = "theme_void()") + theme_void(base_size = 7) (p1 + p2 + p3) / (p4 + p5 + p6) & theme(plot.title = element_text(family = "Roboto Condensed", size = 16), plot.margin = margin(b = 2, r = 1, unit = "lines")) ```
## Main theme components {.medium} ```{r theming} #| echo: true #| eval: false data |> ggplot(aes(x = var1, y = var2)) |> geom_line() + theme_minimal() + theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "red"), panel.grid.x = element_blank(), axis.line.x = element_line(linewidth = 1.2), legend.text = element_text(size = 7), legend.position = "top") ```
::: {.tbl-classic} | Plot | Panel | Axis | Legend | Strip | |------|-------|------|--------|-------| | background | background | title | background | background | | title | border | text | key | placement | | subtitle | grid | ticks | title | text | | caption | spacing | line | text | | | margin | | | position | | ::: ## Bibliography {.bibstyle} :::footer :::
